awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Time Domain Astronomy in the Caribbean: Detecting and Characterizing the Fastest Astrophysical Transient Events
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project seeks to exploit the unique location of the University of the Virgin Islands Robotic Telescope (VIRT) to monitor and detect short-lived (transient) and explosive astronomical events.  The VIRT is in a "blind spot" in the global coverage of astronomical transient events, and its robotic capability allows it to respond within minutes of the identification of such events. This will allow new discoveries as well as rapid monitoring of known transient events from ongoing multi-wavelength observational surveys, allowing astronomers to characterize transient events at multiple wavelengths and understand the mechanisms responsible for them.  By supporting a postdoctoral researcher, this project will strengthen the astronomy research program at the University of the Virgin Islands (UVI).  It will also provide research opportunities for students in the Physics program at UVI. 

The research team will implement a real-time data analysis pipeline for the VIRT, create a lightcurve template database, and build a modern machine-learning infrastructure for rapid classification of astronomical transient events.  The project will bolster the research and education programs at UVI by supporting a dedicated postdoctoral researcher and involving undergraduate students in several aspects of the project.  It will thus help realize UVI?s potential in research and help establish it as a major research and education institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The project main objectives were 1) the implementation of a real-time data analysis pipeline for the Virgin Islands Robotic Telescope; 2) the creation of a lightcurve template database; 3) the creation of a modern machine learning infrastructure for prompt transients classification based on time-domain+multimessenger data.

During the time of the award we were able to accomplish these goals and create useful tools that can be used by other members of the community with no or minimal modification. 

Specifically, the VIRT pipeline can be adapted to other small-medium size observatories at sub-optimal location as the Virgin Islands. Our work on the characterization of the VIRT camera has been fully documented in our publication and the code is publicly available on Github.

The VIRT database is currently ingesting all acquired data (nightly) as well as calibration files and can be searched through a simple web interface. The database is designed to also include fully photometrically calibrated lightcurves of objects of interest.

The team has contributed to an anomaly detection algorithm that has been fully tested and now employed by the Deeper Wider Faster survey for the real-time identification of fast evolving transients.

Finally, we designed a framework that utilizes lightcurves acquired simultanously in different wavelengths to classify astronomical transients. The first successful test was done using the Swift BAT 157-months catalog and its 8 channels. The framework utilizes autoencoder and is designed to incporate data from X-ray to radio.

Results and contributions have been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at national and international conferences.

Broader impact

The activities conducted by the team has been fundamentally intertwined with the University of the Virgin Islands (UVI) and the Territory. 

The PI and his team, in collaboration with other UVI Physics faculty, have exposed students to different aspects of the project: from the code development and testing to the hardware testing and environmental condition analysis, to the exploitation of the scientific images produced and the sientific outcomes. 

Students in Computer Science, Evironmental Studies, Physics (Astronomy and Engineering concentrations) have been engaged during summer research periods, as well as part-time researcher over the school year. 

Similarly, the team has participated in UVI initiatives aimed at in service K-12 teachers and the wider community during "Astronomy Day" where students and the team have showcased their work and the impact it had on their career choices. UVI Physics students, the PI and the team, despite the impact of COVID19, have worked together to make sure younger generations of Virgin Islanders see the field of Astronomy (and Physics) as getaway towards life goals that go beyond a higher education degree.

The physics program has seen a steady graduation tracking record of talented individual, most of which are now pursuing Master and Ph.D. programs across the nation. Despite the pandemic, 2022 academic year has shown indication that the program is still strong and seen as a valuable option for students interested in Physicsl Science, especially Physics/Engineering and astronomy.
